user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_BSP_Setup:
```c
void UT_BSP_Setup(void)
{
    uint8        UserShift;
    uint32       ArgC;
    char *const *ArgV;

    memset(&BSP_UT_Global, 0, sizeof(BSP_UT_Global));

    UserShift = UTASSERT_CASETYPE_NONE;
    ArgC      = OS_BSP_GetArgC();
    if (ArgC > 0)
    {
        ArgV = OS_BSP_GetArgV();
        while (ArgC > 0)
        {
            --ArgC;

            if (strcmp(ArgV[0], "-d") == 0)
            {
                UserShift = UTASSERT_CASETYPE_DEBUG;
            }
            if (strcmp(ArgV[0], "-q") == 0)
            {
                UserShift = UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE;
            }
            if (strcmp(ArgV[0], "-v") == 0 && ArgC > 0)
            {
                --ArgC;
                UserShift = strtoul(ArgV[1], NULL, 0);
                ++ArgV;
            }

            ++ArgV;
        }
    }

    if (UserShift == UTASSERT_CASETYPE_NONE || UserShift >= UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MAX)
    {
        UserShift = UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS;
    }

    BSP_UT_Global.CurrVerbosity = (2 << UserShift) - 1;

    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_BEGIN, "UNIT TEST");
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function UT_BSP_Setup:
typedef uint32_t  uint32
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (ArgC > 0)
    {
        ArgV = OS_BSP_GetArgV();
        while (ArgC > 0)
        {
            --ArgC;

            if (strcmp(ArgV[0], "-d") == 0)
            {
                UserShift = UTASSERT_CASETYPE_DEBUG;
            }
            if (strcmp(ArgV[0], "-q") == 0)
            {
                UserShift = UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE;
            }
            if (strcmp(ArgV[0], "-v") == 0 && ArgC > 0)
            {
                --ArgC;
                UserShift = strtoul(ArgV[1], NULL, 0);
                ++ArgV;
            }

            ++ArgV;
        }
    }
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: all branches in the fragment are conditional on runtime values (ArgC/ArgV) and therefore reachable depending on inputs. The outer if and while guard execution when ArgC>0, and the '-v' case includes an ArgC>0 check before accessing ArgV[1], so there is no statically unreachable code in this fragment.
